title: Before 1 January 2021, will the Russian constitution be amended to allow Vladimir Putin to remain president after his current term?

The commission estimated the turnout was 65% of eligible voters."

Last year polls indicated a 68% popular approval of changing term limits (https://www.dw.com/en/russian-parliament-fast-tracks-putins-constitutional-changes/a-52106277).   Most people have predicted Putin would move to make this extension but has delayed until the timing shows a greater need (or greater instability), I think.  So given that Putin usually moves quickly and steadily through procedures once he starts managing the process and also that these changes were pushed through the DUMA quite quickly in January over the course of a week, most likely handed down to the DUMA by Putin for a fast "committee" to suggest, very shortly after the COVID-19 became known and predicted to spread widely when both need and the potential for political and economic (ergo social) instability could increasingly justify it, a final move to ratify the changes in the Duma seems likely to occur within a month of the July 1 popular "vote."  https://www.dw.com/en/russian-parliament-fast-tracks-putins-constitutional-changes/a-52106277

Two milestones will mark Russia’s national day this year. The first is the number of covid-19 cases, which has surpassed 500,000, the third-highest of any country. The second is the lifting of lockdown restrictions, amid one of the world’s lowest official death rates—something that the World Health Organisation said was “difficult to understand”. It has not considered the interests of Vladimir Putin. On July 1st Russia will vote on constitutional changes that will allow its autocratic president to stay in power beyond 2024. Yet his approval rating has plummeted. To lift the nation’s mood, he decided it was time to end the lockdown. From this week, Muscovites can go outside and use public transport as normal.

The current Russian constitution is the second-longest lived in the history of Russia (26 years 8 months), behind only the 1936 Constitution (41 years). The average lifespan of a Russian constitution is 23 years 9 months, with a lowest deviation of 32.6% (8 years) and highest deviation of 72.6% (17 years). Therefore, the current constitution is expected to last between 17 years 3 months and 41 years 0 months. with 26 years 8 months, the constitution is at 72.4% of its expected lifespan range. (73% base odds)
Putin's current approval ratings are 69%, which is below average for his tenure, but on the rise since last year. After previous dips in approval ratings (2005, 2013) approval numbers quickly increased and remained stable for a number of years. Presidents acting during states of emergency have better odds of being reelected. Putin has functioned as (acting) president of Russia for 17 years (212.5% of the usual 8 years). Medvedev and the entire cabinet have already resigned on 15 January 2020 in order for Putin to make constitutional changes that would "significantly change Russia's balance of power", and the government has been continuing their duties as a mere caretaker government since. This is a politically undesirable situation to sustain for beyond 2020.
I have no doubt that Putin will amend the constitution to extend his terms beyond 2025, but Covid-19 does allow (unlikely) for delays beyond 2020. Taking into account the amount of political power that Putin wields in Russia also increases likelihood.
While the legislation still needs to be approved by Russia's Constitutional Court and a referendum, this seems a mere formality.

As per the provisions of the Constitution, Putin is not allowed to stand for Presidency in 2024. The constitutional amendment allows Putin to another 2 terms till 2036. The Duma has already approved the amendment and the referendum is only a technical requirement. Hence, there is no urgency to hold the referendum due to the ongoing Pandemic crisis.  The referendum depends upon the flattening of the Pandemic curve and upon the mitigation of the economic consequences. Hence, the priority for Putin is to normalize the situation before the referendum. On another note, Putin has not clearly expressed his intent after 2024. He may nominate a successor, loyal to him and his policies.  Overall, there are urgent priorities and sufficient time that makes holding a referendum not an immediate priority.

The most difficult factor is whether it will be adopted in 2021 with the Coronavirus situation. Putin will want to do the voting as quickly as possible. With 8 months left I think it is 95% likely that the vote will be held in 2021 => 0.95*0.95 = 0.9025 = 90%
Seems likely to occur, the question is timing.

Because he has already proposed a change to the constitution of this kind but it was delayed because of COVID19. However, constitutional changes are difficult even in a country like Russia, which has a high tolerance of authoritarian leaders. Constitutional law is foundational and requires greater voting rights than a regular law change.

It is more than likely that this constitutional change will be enacted by January 2021 because it is being voted on with a wave of other constitutional changes. Additionally, the current global economy, COVID-19 situation, and oil pricing wars impact Russia uniquely and signal a high level of impending uncertainty. Many of the constitutional changes include changing Russian laws regarding international norms, the race to enhance Russia's position as a global and strategic influence, and the proliferation of Russia's military, as well as improvements surrounding pensions and the slowing birth-rate. The mere-exposure effect demonstrates that many people will support a candidate based on their presence in the media and name recognition, therefore this demonstrates that many Russian people, who have witnessed Putin's twenty years in office hold a, "if not Putin, then who?" mentality. Lastly, both the Duma and various regional legislators in Russia have already endorsed this move, which reflects early support that will allow for a large margin of time to gain momentum between now and January 2021.

First, I am going with the crowd to some degree.  Putin usually gets what he wants.  Covid-19 seems to be pushing autocratically inclined leaders to be more autocratic.  That is one factor.  Low oil prices for the foreseeable future means suffering and discontent in Russia.  Putin will want to get this amendment through before there is increased restiveness in the population,

The pretend referendum is after all a pretend referendum, and the Duma and the courts are stuffed with Putin's sock puppets.   The constitution will certainly be amended, probably in time for his birthday.  This may not have the long-term effect that Vlad the Shirtless contemplates, since hardly anybody likes him any more, but that's not the question.   For what will happen when he finally dies or is retired to a lovely dacha somewhere, watch the dandy 2017 film "The Death of Stalin" again.  Then (if you haven't done it lately or don't remember), look up what became of the surviving main characters.  I'll bet the whole thing  will, mutatis mutandis, be surprisingly predictive.

Process to occurring
1) Amendment submitted to Duma - Occurred
2) National vote (non-binding) - Polls show support leads by c 10%. Churches backed reform
- However delay due to COVID - Schedule for 22nd April delayed
- Oil price collapse. 
3)  Court approved - Very likely Putin has changed direction before, and there are many mechanisms for him ensuring he has control without title of 'president'. Paths to consider:
0) Will Putin use a different mechanism to retain power? 33%
1) Will vote be delayed to beyond this year (reasonable time to do so given term in until 2024) - 50% due to COVID and oil
2) Will Putin win the vote and therefore be able to take this route? 80% Therefore prob is 66%*50%*80* = 27%

* President Putin hadls enjoyed a fairly consistent level of publuc support in Russia throughout his long "career".
* He has not indicated that he is working on preparing a successor to his "reign" and therefore he would certainly want to remain in power. 
* While the vote was delayed, ultimately this is a very high priority for Putin, so it is bound to happen before it is too late.
